text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Bulgaria is expected to raise central heating charges by 12 percent from July 1, Energy Committee officials said.
-- Bulgaria's State Railways said it would repay its debts to Romania amounting to about three million Swiss francs by deliveries of train electric batteries.
-- Bulgaria's parliament raised the threshold for registration of local businessmen under the Value Added Tax law to 75 million levs from 7.5 million levs to adjust the threshold to inflation rate.
-- Bulgaria is expected to seek a $26 million loan from the World Bank to restructure its health care system, Health minister Petar Boyadziev said.
-- Bulgaria should step up fight against illegal imports and local production of fake whisky brands, a visiting British trade official said.

-- Officials from Bulgaria's private Slavyani bank, which has been in receivership since September 1996, have siphoned abroad some 1.2 billion levs through companies based in Canada and in the Dominican Republic, Interior ministry secretary Georgi Georgiev said.
-- Bulgaria's state National Television said it would cut 800 jobs in line with government's policy to curb budget spendings.
-- Czech Republic's Union bank is interested in acquiring a stake in Bulgaria's state Hebrosbank, Bulgaria's Bank Consolidation Company executive director Dimitar Dimitrov said. @
-- Bulgaria's parliament raised excise duties on gambling three-fold bringing the fee per a roulette table in a casino to 72 million levs annually.
-- The Shell Transport and Trading Co group said it was interested in the planned privatisation of Bulgaria's biggest oil refinery Neftochim.

-- Bulgaria plans to establish a national gendarmerie force to guard strategic sites like the nuclear power plant in Koslodui and the country's coal-fired power plants, Interior ministry secretary Lyutskan Lyutskanov said. @

-- Bulgaria's Podkrepa Trade Union president Konstantin Trenchev said he had submited information to Bulgarian police about real estate property in the United States recently acquired by Bulgarians through possible siphoning of state funds abroad.
-- British investments in Bulgaria amounted to some $5.7 million this year so far, Bulgarian Trade Minister Valentin Vassilev said. -- Sofia Newsroom, (++359-2) 981 8569
